metadata.case_name: Returned Candidates (Congress) v. Jan Sangh Candidates (Election Petitioners)

facts.text: General election to Lok Sabha held in March 1971 in South Delhi Constituency and Delhi-Sadar Constituency.
Appellants were successful candidates contesting on behalf of Congress party with symbol cow and calf; declared elected.
Unsuccessful Jan Sangh candidates (election petitioners, respondents here) challenged validity of appellants' election on ground of rigging by ruling party.
Alleged rigging process: Millions of ballot papers chemically treated; Congress symbol mechanically stamped with invisible ink; mark disappears after few days, stamped symbol emerges.

Election Commission instructed Returning Officers to forward substantial ballot papers to Delhi ostensibly for scrutiny but to carry out design; replaced with chemically treated and stamped papers used in election.
Election Commission alterations: Larger interval between polling and counting; mixing ballot papers from various booths and rotating in drums.

At counting: Colour of large number of ballot papers different; stamping uniform at identical spot; stamps uniform in density, bright and fresh; dissimilar to other papers including those for defeated candidates.
Affidavits of two persons present at counting supporting observations.
Rumours of rigging; landslide victory of ruling party unexpected; huge quantity of unused ballot papers found in Chandigarh godown.
Delhi High Court (Andley J.) permitted inspection of ballot papers by judgments dated September 3, 1971 and August 6, 1971 in I.A. No. 1170/1971 in Election Petition Nos. 1 and 2 of 1971.
No direct evidence claimed by election petitioners; seek to prove by examination of ballot papers.
Attention of Returning Officer/Assistant Returning Officer allegedly invited to strange features at counting, but controversy not resolved at this stage.

legal_issues.text: Whether inspection of ballot papers should be permitted in the election petitions challenging the validity of the appellants' election on allegations of rigging.

petitioner_arguments.text: Allegations are propaganda stunts devoid of truth; scrutiny of ballot papers serious matter; secrecy of ballot utmost importance; inspection only on very good grounds.
At counting, attention of Returning Officer not invited to strange features; no objection to acceptance of alleged spurious papers.
Petitioners failed to make out case for inspection; allegations not probable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Sewak Yadav v. Hussain Kamil Kidwai; Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh; Jitendra Bahadur Singh v. Krishna Behari

respondent_arguments.text: Main ground: Ruling party rigged election through chemical treatment and invisible ink stamping; changes in procedure to facilitate.
Observations at counting support rigging; affidavits filed; circumstances like rumours, victory, unused papers.
Only way to prove/disprove is by inspecting ballot papers.

court_reasoning.text: Unable to comprehend theories but cannot reject without scrutiny; allegations serious, challenge integrity of Election Commission; public interest to expose falsity if propaganda.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confidence in democratic institutions at stake; allow enquiry to build public confidence.

court_reasoning.text: Trial judge held allegations bona fide and serious, calling for investigation; agree.
Inspection allowed if necessary in interests of justice; no rigid rules; must have material facts, bona fide, not vague; secrecy important but justice more so.
Analyzed precedents: Inspection not routine; requires material facts enabling court to consider justice; no fishing enquiry.

Allegations provable only by inspection; limit to sample (600 for each returned candidate, 200 for petitioners) for initial check; if needed, further probe with experts, then general inspection maintaining secrecy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No general inspection until satisfactory proof.

holdings.text: Inspection of ballot papers permissible if allegations supported by material facts, bona fide, and necessary in interests of justice; secrecy important but justice overrides, especially for public interest.
Allow limited/sample inspection initially; if warranted, further evidence and possible general inspection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Sewak Yadav v. Hussain Kamil Kidwai
precedents_cited.relevance: Inspection only if necessary in interests of justice; mere production of ballot boxes does not entitle to inspection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal can order inspection under s.92 RPA; requires concise material facts; no vague allegations; interests of justice overriding, no fishing; secrecy to be borne in mind.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jitendra Bahadur Singh v. Krishna Behari
precedents_cited.relevance: Vague/indefinite allegations without material facts do not justify inspection.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of Tribunal for discovery/inspection; election petition must contain concise statement of material facts.

outcome.summary: Appeals against Delhi High Court order permitting inspection dismissed; directed limited/sample inspection of ballot papers (600 for each returned candidate from different bundles, 200 for petitioners) initially by trial judge with parties; if needed, further evidence/experts then possible general inspection maintaining secrecy.
outcome.relief_granted: Limited inspection of ballot papers as directed.

key_quotes.text: "We shall accept nothing and reject nothing except on satisfactory proof."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Approach to serious allegations of electoral rigging.

key_quotes.text: "The allegation that our electoral process has been fouled is a very serious allegation... What is more important is the survival of the very democratic institutions."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights public importance of investigating election integrity.

key_quotes.text: "Secrecy of ballot is important, but doing justice is undoubtedly more important and it would be more so, if what is in stake is the interests of the society."
key_quotes.speaker: court
